title: 110_s755
content: The "Diabetes Screening and Medicaid Savings Act of 2007" improves diabetes screening and treatment under Medicaid. The "Diabetes Screening and Medicaid Savings Act of 2007" enhances diabetes screening for adult enrollees with diabetes risk factors by including diabetes screening tests at appropriate intervals. The term "individual at risk for diabetes" includes individuals 45 years or older who are overweight and individuals under 45 who are overweight with specific risk factors for diabetes. These risk factors include having a first-degree relative with diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, being habitually inactive, or being a member of high-risk ethnic populations for diabetes. The term "individual at risk for diabetes" includes those with specific risk factors such as family history, hypertension, and belonging to high-risk ethnic populations. Amendments to the Social Security Act now provide a comprehensive package of benefits for individuals with diabetes. The Social Security Act now includes provisions for individuals diagnosed with diabetes to receive specific medical assistance, including essential care and services prescribed by their healthcare provider. The Social Security Act provides medical assistance for individuals with diabetes, including prescriptions, durable medical equipment, pregnancy services, eye exams, podiatric services, and diabetes education. The Social Security Act provides medical assistance for individuals with diabetes, including outpatient self-management training services and medical nutrition therapy services. Cost sharing is prohibited for individuals diagnosed with diabetes for specified items and services. The Social Security Act prohibits cost sharing for individuals diagnosed with diabetes or related complications. Amendments to the Act will take effect on October 1, 2007. Amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2007. For State plans under title XIX of the Social Security Act that require legislative changes to meet the new requirements, they will not be considered non-compliant solely for not meeting these requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the state legislature's session following the enactment of the Act. In a State with a 2-year legislative session, each year is considered a separate regular session of the State legislature.
